title: 105_hr1838
content:
The Act titled "Coast Guard Authorization Act for Fiscal Years 1998 and 1999" authorizes appropriations. Funds are authorized for Coast Guard expenses in fiscal year 1998, including operation and maintenance, acquisition of navigation aids and facilities, vessels, and aircraft, and research and development for mission improvement. The Coast Guard is allocated $19,000,000 for various missions including search and rescue, marine safety, and defense readiness. Additionally, $645,696,000 is designated for retired pay and medical care of retired personnel. Environmental compliance and restoration at Coast Guard facilities also receive funding. The Coast Guard is allocated $21,000,000 for guard facilities functions, $2,740,000,000 for operation and maintenance, and $379,000,000 for acquisition and construction of aids to navigation, vessels, and aircraft for fiscal year 1999. The Oil Pollution Act of 1990 allocated $19,000,000 for research and development related to improving the Coast Guard's mission, with $3,500,000 from the Oil Spill Liability Trust Fund. Additionally, funds were designated for retired pay, survivor benefits, and medical care for retired personnel and their dependents. For environmental compliance and restoration at Coast Guard facilities functions, $21,000,000 is allocated to remain available until expended. SEC. 102. AUTHORIZED LEVELS OF MILITARY STRENGTH AND TRAINING. The Coast Guard is authorized specific end-of-year strength levels for active duty personnel and military training student loads for fiscal years 1998 and 1999. For flight training, professional training in military and civilian institutions, and officer acquisition, student years as necessary. TITLE II--PERSONNEL MANAGEMENT

SEC. 201. REMOVE CAP ON WARRANT OFFICER SEVERANCE PAY.

SEC. 202. SPECIAL RECRUITING AUTHORITY. Section 93 of title 14, United States Code is amended to address underrepresentation of minorities in the Coast Guard by obtaining research on personnel resource and training needs, and implementing special programs for recruiting minorities with financial assistance. The special recruiting authority for minorities in the Coast Guard will expire on December 31, 2002. Before any extension, the Secretary must report to Congress on program funds and effectiveness in increasing minority representation. TITLE III--FINANCIAL AND PROPERTY MANAGEMENT

SEC. 301. USE OF APPROPRIATED FUNDS FOR COMMERCIAL VEHICLES AT MILITARY FUNERALS. Amends Section 93 of title 14, United States Code to allow for the rental or lease of commercial vehicles to transport next of kin of eligible retired Coast Guard military personnel to attend funeral services at a national cemetery.

SEC. 302. AUTHORITY TO REIMBURSE NOVATO, CALIFORNIA, REUSE COMMISSION. SEC. 302. AUTHORITY TO REIMBURSE NOVATO, CALIFORNIA, REUSE COMMISSION. The Commandant may use up to $25,000 for economic adjustment assistance for the City of Novato, California, to revise the Hamilton Reuse Planning Authority's plan due to the Coast Guard's housing request at Hamilton Air Force Base. If the Department of Defense provides assistance on behalf of the Coast Guard, reimbursement is allowed. SEC. 303 amends subsection 650(a) of title 14, United States Code, to eliminate the supply fund reimbursement requirement. The fund will be credited with the value of materials consumed, issued for use, sold, or disposed of, covering the cost thereof. SEC. 304 grants authority to implement and fund certain awards programs. Section 93 of title 14, United States Code is amended to provide for the honorary recognition of individuals and organizations contributing to Coast Guard programs, missions, or operations, with the provision of plaques, medals, trophies, badges, and similar items funded by the Coast Guard. TITLE IV--REPORTS AND INVESTIGATIONS

SEC. 401. PROTECT MARINE CASUALTY INVESTIGATIONS FROM MANDATORY RELEASE. Amends Section 6305 of title 46, United States Code by removing subsection (a) and subsection (b).

SEC. 402. ELIMINATE BIENNIAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT REPORT. Amends Section 7001 of the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 by removing subsection (e) and redesignating subsection (f) as subsection (e).

TITLE V--MARINE SAFETY AND ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION

SEC. 501. EXTENSION OF TERRITORIAL SEA FOR CERTAIN LAWS. The Ports and Waterways Safety Act is amended to include the territorial sea of the United States as navigable waters. Title 46 of the United States Code is also amended to reflect this change. The Ports and Waterways Safety Act is amended to include the territorial sea of the United States as navigable waters in various sections of Title 46 of the United States Code. The Ports and Waterways Safety Act is amended in various sections of Title 46 of the United States Code to include the territorial sea of the United States as navigable waters within 3 nautical miles from the baselines. The Ports and Waterways Safety Act is amended to include the territorial sea of the United States as navigable waters within 3 nautical miles from the baselines, as described in Presidential Proclamation 5928 of December 27, 1988. SEC. 502. MANDATORY SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION FOR MERCHANT MARINER LICENSES. Amends Section 7703 of title 46, United States Code to allow suspension or revocation of licenses for mariners with charges or convictions of offenses.
